newsitem.title: USA: U.S. adj retail sales up 0.6 pct in April - Redbook.
newsitem.headline: U.S. adj retail sales up 0.6 pct in April - Redbook.

text.p: U.S. seasonally adjusted retail sales rose 0.6 percent in the first week of fiscal April versus March, according to the Lynch, Jones & Ryan Inc Redbook Retail Sales Index.
The index rose 6.5 percent compared to the same month a year ago, the report said. Adjusted retail sales rose 6.5 percent in the week ended April 12 compared with the same week a year ago, it said.
Sales for the week were somewhat below stores' plans, Howard Eilenberg, retail analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan, said in an interview with Reuters Financial Television.
"We're still running on the momentum from earlier in the year, but my sense is (sales are) are running out of steam," Eilenberg said.
The underlying strength in the economy has helped bolster the retail sector, he said.
So far in April, Eilenberg said, apparel in general and women's sportswear in specific sold well, while durable goods have been "a tough sell."
If sales fail to accelerate in coming weeks, retailers may expand promotional discounts, the analyst said.
